mdRecord.dcterms:title: Letter, George Washington, Newburgh, to Governor Benjamin Harrison, 1783 March 19
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Washington, George, 1732-1799
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Written from Newburgh while facing a mutiny due to a lack of soldier's pay and supplies, George Washington appealed to Virginia's governor, Benjamin Harrison, for financial support of his troops. Referencing an earlier letter, he began, “About the first of this Month I wrote you along letter. I touched upon the state of the Army. …I little expected at the time of writing that letter, that we were on the eve of an important crisis to this Army; when the touch stone of discord was to be applied—and the virtue of its members to undergo the severest trial.” Newburgh conspiracy. Autograph letter signed, 4 pages.
